title: Fact Check: Did BJP in Delhi lose 8 seats by margin of less than 100 votes? - Times of India
subtitle: News News: A message going viral across social media platforms claims that BJP lost a total of 8 seats by a margin of less than 100 votes, 19 seats by less than
author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
vclaim: A message going viral across social media platforms claims that BJP lost a total of 8 seats by a margin of less than 100 votes, 19 seats by less than 1000 votes and 9 seats by less than 2000 votes, in the just concluded Delhi assembly elections.The message claims that had there been 3% more voter turnout, the entire ‘game’ would have changed in favour of BJP and it would have ended up bagging 44 seats out of 70.The message is also being circulated in the form of a graphic card across Twitter and WhatsApp The claim is false. The BJP lost just two seats by a margin of less than 2000 votes.Using keyword ‘Delhi elections margin’ on Google search, we found a news report by Hindustan Times titled ‘13 seats that saw the closest contests in Delhi assembly election’. The report claims that there were only 13 constituencies where victory margins ranged from below 7,000 votes.Out of these 13 constituencies, BJP lost two seats namely Bijwasan and Adarsh Nagar to AAP by a margin of less than 2000 votes.AAP’s Bhupinder Singh Joon from Bijwasan, a fresh face and a lawyer who replaced the party's disqualified MLA Devender Sehrawat, defeated the BJP’s Sat Prakash Rana by only 753 votes.AAP’s Pawan Sharma form Adarsh Nagar, another fresh face, defeated BJP’s Raj Kumar Bhatia by 1,589 votes.Looking up on the official website of the Election Commission of India, we confirmed that only these two seats were lost by BJP to AAP by a margin of less than 2000 votes.This proves that the lowest margin for loss in Delhi was 753 votes, so question of BJP losing even a single seat by less than 100 votes doesn't arise.Times Fact Check has found the claims of BJP losing 8 seats in Delhi assembly elections by margin of less than 100 votes to be false.
